awd_titl_txt: Whom Can I Trust?   A Cooperative Contingencies Framework for Predicting and Reducing Intergroup Bias
awd_abstract_narration:
Despite a substantial decline in overt prejudice and discrimination, intergroup disparities persist.  The research will test key hypotheses derived from a novel "cooperative contingencies" framework that can account for biased and discriminatory behavior among otherwise low prejudiced people.  Shared group memberships enhance cooperation, which often provides a powerful instrumental incentive for individuals, regardless of prejudice level, to preferentially affiliate with ingroup over outgroup members.  Critically, incentives to preferentially affiliate are likely to be contingent on the full set of cooperative affordances available in an environment. If shared group memberships afford the best available means of facilitating cooperation between individuals, people are likely to preferentially rely on ingroup members.  However, when effective non-group based mechanisms for fostering and sustaining cooperation are present or when groups are not likely to enhance cooperation, individuals low (but not high) in prejudice are less likely to exhibit intergroup biases.  This hypothesis is particularly important because it suggests that external social structures and institutions that facilitate cooperation among individuals (e.g., sanctions for non-cooperation, rule of law) may cause people to rely less on shared group memberships and thereby reduce intergroup bias.

Scientifically, this approach to understanding and reducing bias in favor of one's group is complementary to and advances on existing theories on intergroup relations.  Importantly, it can account for a range of phenomena and generate predictions that extant approaches do not.  This research is also directly relevant to a pressing societal problem.  By focusing on the instrumental incentives that can drive bias among low-prejudiced people and examining the influence of situational aspects on these processes, this research promises to inform new interventions for reducing prejudice and discrimination.  In addition to the sorts of educational and training programs that have been developed to combat such bias, leaders and policy-makers may also have a range of structural tools at their disposal. Scientifically-informed use of cooperation-enhancing social structures may provide a powerful means of reducing the biased choices that lead to wide-spread intergroup disparities.  This project also includes extensive educational training and knowledge mobilization components.  Graduate and undergraduate students will work closely with the researcher on all aspects of the research, and will have substantial presentation and publication opportunities.  Research findings will be publicized in local and national media and presented in public lectures.

por.por_cntn:
This project was designed to examine disparities in the degree to which people trust ingroup vs. outgroup members, and to investigate the potential for cooperation-facilitating social institutions to reduce intergroup trust disparities.  The project also included educational training and knowledge mobilization components, providing graduate and undergraduate students opportunities for involvement in all stages of the research process. 

We conducted a number of experiments to investigate intergroup cooperative dynamics.  Main results of interest were as follows.  (1) Across a range of different paradigms, the presence of effective cooperation-facilitating institutions (e.g., third party punishers) increased intergroup cooperation.  These increases were generally greatest for individuals with egalitarian goals or who were low in prejudice.  (2) The presence of effective cooperation-facilitating institutions was also observed to reduce implicit racial bias.  (3) The belief that ingroup members are more trustworthy may make individuals vulnerable to deception by reducing scrutiny of information from ingroup sources. (4) In non-competitive contexts, perceivers appear to make dispositional inferences about trustworthiness when observing outgroup members behaving cooperatively, potentially increasing intergroup trust.  (5) Contrary to predictions, egalitarian individuals may not trust biased ingroup members more in contexts that require cooperation.

These results contribute to social psychology by informing our understanding of how needs for cooperation and effective social institutions can influence intergroup bias. The results also provide evidence for a form of rapid evaluative tuning that has not previously been demonstrated in the discipline; namely, that rapid evaluations of ingroup and outgroup members shift as a function of whether there are institutions in place that can facilitate cooperation between individuals.  These findings in particular contribute to an evolving understanding of the flexible and dynamic nature of implicit evaluations. This project also included the development of a novel decision-making/choice paradigm to investigate intergroup biases in partner selection in interpersonal contexts that require trust. The advantages of this paradigm include an ability to index opportunity costs incurred when individuals selectively choose to trust ingroup over outgroup members.  We hope that this paradigm will prove a useful tool for further exploration of these dynamics within social psychology and other disciplines.

Finally, this project contributed substantially to the training of multiple graduate and undergraduate students at Lehigh University.  Students worked on all stages of the research process, presented results at scientific conferences (e.g., Society of Personality and Social Psychology, Association for Psychological Science, Psychonomic Society), and prepared findings for publication in peer-reviewed journals (e.g., Social Cognition).
